review_title: Good stable job that gives you room to grow.
pros: Once you learn the job and computer system its pretty easy office work. Decent benefits 401k, health insurance. There is some room for advancement, make it clear to the supervisor/manager that you are looking to climb the corporate ladder, there are usually positions that open up giving you that opportunity. Usually able to get a couple of extra hours of overtime per week, if you want, but not required. Some remote work opportunities.
cons: Supervisors can be amazing or subpar, that can make a huge difference for you. And there is a lot of turnover in those positions, so that can be good or bad, depending on if you like your supervisor. Job can get a bit mindnumbing after awhile. Often required to work some weekends or nights.

pros: Great benefits, and good DEI culture. There are a lot of separate teams and each team has a different management style. A lot of professional development time if offered, and can take plenty of PTO.
cons: A lot of work for an academic coach, little department support, and too many learners per cohort. Technology and software could be better performed before being launched. Very over worked, easily stressed with the workload.

pros: The downtown location was convenient for walking to food places at lunch.
cons: Managers were often catty, unprofessional, conniving, and over-the-top demanding - to a level of bullying. It felt like an adult high school. Super toxic personalities and passive-aggressive communication. My manager treated me like her scapegoat anytime she made mistakes in her job (blaming people below her was easier than taking responsiblity - she protected her job by finding excuses for her failures). She would often re-present my work in meetings, as her own, claiming credit for my ideas and never telling people the work she was being credited for was my work. Behind closed doors, employees often gossiped about each other and complained about how much they hated working there which created a negative and fake work culture. I heard people throwing each other under the bus and backstabbing often. The Capella business is also shady and unethical - many students paid a lot of money for their online degrees only to learn afterward that the degrees they completed were useless and unaccredited. It was heartbreaking.

pros: Great leadership teams at Capella!
cons: Everyday on a phone queue.

review_title: Not for profit, not for people either
job_title: Financial Aid Advisor in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Can work from home, good benefits
cons: poor supervisor, management is for themselves and not their subordinates, too many ill-practices being swept under the rug, failure to comply with ADA paperwork and practices, fire employs for standing up for themselves and speaking up

job_title: Account Development Manager in Minneapolis, MN
pros: overall good culture and product
cons: The market has caught up with the fully online for-profits.

pros: Amazing company culture, great leaders
cons: Pay, change management, job preference

pros: I was able to move up in the company after starting as a graduate assistant while in my masters program.
cons: No cons for me as I’m still working there

pros: Good faculty to work with. Good students. The program is well-developed. Many other opportunities for career growth.
cons: Poor benefits for f/t employees.

pros: Lots of learning opportunities, as a benefit and on job learning.
cons: Rhetoric doesn’t match reality. Projects rarely succeed, so many fires.

pros: Making a difference to higher education learners
cons: Many meetings, a lot of busywork in addition to teaching courses

pros: Good place for those just starting in educational technology
cons: Very poor place for those who are seasoned in Ed tech and are looking to push the boundaries of what can be done.

pros: I am proud to be on staff for this university. While a for-profit school, Capella University focuses on student learning and career outcomes, trusting the bottom line will follow. Capella is one of only a few schools approved by the DOE to offer competency-based programs: with its optional FlexPath route you can move through classes by demonstrating you have learned the subject matter. Compare that to traditional credit-hour courses which force you to do a certain number of hours of work per week, whether actually needed in your case or not.
cons: In 2018, when their parent companies merged, Capella gained a sister in the form of Strayer University, which has demanded extra attention.

pros: Good Onboarding and training for new hires
cons: Not much upward career mobility

pros: You can end up with a great supervisor who provides flexibility, encouragement, and advocates for your success.
cons: As pressures to become more corporate and consistent rise, company culture and connectivity are faltering. You could have a supervisor who is so focused on their own growth that they're unnecessarily harsh, critical, and traditional.

pros: Great team and department culture. Downtown location is a plus!
cons: Many leadership transitions. Expect to work with at least 2-3 different supervisors and managers per year.

pros:
-There are programs for growth and development at all levels.
-Work-life balances
-Great co-workers and peers
cons:
-I don't feel management cares for its employees
-Capacity has been a concern for two years
-Silo their departments
-Advocate change for change/processes but no follow through

review_title: Constant change in leadership and expectations.
pros: Wonderful co-workers, decent benefits, hybrid or remote work available.
cons: Tone-def executive leadership, "do more with less" approach, downhill culture since merger with Strayer University, mixed messages, favoritism.

pros: very communicative with their employees
cons: there seems to be favoritism

pros: Culture and integrity, DEI focus.
cons: Salary is low for being an academic position with 2 Graduation Degrees.

pros: Culture, work from home full time
cons: Do a lot of work, grind all day, get paid not well.

pros: Awesome colleagues, overall fun company culture, good intentions
cons: Promoting the wrong people, metrics focused, immediate manager controls your promotion opportunity

job_title: Financial Aid Administrator in Carlisle, AR
pros: Caring Management, flexible hours, helpful feedback from managers, helpful co-workers, no-stress
cons: Cannot think of any at this time.

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Capella has the most supportive culture I have ever been a part of. You know the organization values you, and your leadership wants to help you reach your career goals.
cons: Not competitive pay- but the benefits are great

pros: Capella has warm and supportive staff.
cons: There could have been better communication when starting.

job_title: Enrollment Services Representative in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Great Leadership. Reasonable Pay. Great income. Room for Growth.
cons: Sometimes it can feel a bit detached from a remote environment.

pros:
Culture is good on the surface 
Fun atmosphere
cons: There’s some middle aged white men in power that tend to stick together at the cost of the company and it’s employees

review_title: It has gotten a LOT worse since the Strayer merger...
pros:
- There are some fantastic people at Capella/SEI
- Generous PTO, but only if you are salaried or have been there for a long time
- They are FINALLY starting to buy into advancing technology, which is ironic, because it's an online university
- Working remote
- Free food came around often (when we were in the office)
cons:
Things have been getting progressively worse since we merged with Strayer. I thought I would be in this job very, VERY long term, but I am starting to look elsewhere since opportunities internally are slim and they basically want you to do stretch roles to fill in the gaps for teams who have lost members, but a lot of the time, it's just a dead end because they won't get the funds to backfill a role, so they're just getting the labor done at a lesser cost. 

We are losing people left and right. It is difficult.

Overall, teams are not fully staffed, colleagues are overworked and underpaid and the excuses we get are laughable. Some Academic Coaches have over 800 learners assigned to them. It is INSANE.

Your leader REALLY shapes your experience at the company. I have had many leaders in my years that I have worked there, some have been great, some have been downright terrible. I have been harassed/verbally assaulted by a leader and nothing happened, in fact, he's now in a very high leadership role. 

Sexism, racism, and microaggressions are a thing. They are claiming they are working on diversity, but I can't help but side-eye that. 

Male leaders promote their "bros" to roles rather than the most qualified person, especially to leadership positions. Then you hear them all chat about how they all go golfing.

Merit increases in the past year were hilariously low - they didn't even match the cost of living increase. However, the company didn't have to pay as much for utilities at offices, office supplies, coffee refills, bagel fridays, etc....Then, they laid a bunch of people off, and can't give those who keep the business running an adequate pay increase after the most stressful, difficult, hardworking year we've ever had where we were doing the jobs of our colleagues who were laid off. VERY FRUSTRATING.

Most of the time, if you're quiet, you are pushed to be a type-A personality kind of person, which can be stressful

Everything is very siloed and there are MANY hoops to jump through to get a project rolling. It is very inefficient and frustrating.

Too many meetings. When is there actually time to get things done?

The investment in tech that they have made, while good-intentioned, is not adequate. It is all over the place. They have not invested in overall training for staff to understand the new things. Leadership takes the stance of "just let them click around and figure it out"

Overall, staff is not tech savvy. This creates a lot of difficulty in communication and getting things done. 

Our benefits package has gotten a lot worse since the strayer merger. Not a fan. They also reduced things like allowed bereavement time from a week to 3 days. That's messed up.

Priorities are all over the place. Sometimes the focus is on the wrong, least important thing.

job_title: Financial Aid Specialist in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Good work life balance, benefits
cons: Don't expect to get any kind of significant raise no matter how well you perform based on their process

review_title: Beware of the Financial Aid Department
job_title: Financial Aid Advisor in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Learn about the ins and outs of financial aid and how to explain complicated topics in laymen’s term.
cons:
Micro managed 
Metrics, metics, metrics 
Petty much a call center 
Quantity over quality 
Supervisors know less that you do
Hired as a temp 
A lot of knowledge to learn with only 2-4 weeks of training. I’m talking about learning flex path, traditional financial aid and business office subjects in only 4 weeks.
No deviation from everyday schedule.
High turnover rate.
You have to work a late night once a week, to 11:30-8:00pm and 4 Saturdays a year.
Can’t do too much when you end up talking to rude and entitled students

pros: I encountered some of the most intelligent, skilled, and friendly people I've ever met during my time at Capella.
cons: The company takes advantage of underserved student populations and charges them exorbitant tuition for programs they aren't yet equipped to complete, thereby trapping many working-class people of color into six-figure student loan debt with no employment potential. My conscience simply wouldn't allow me to stay any longer.

job_title: Senior Financial Aid Advisor in Minneapolis, MN
pros: The position started with the intention to help learners learn about responsible borrowing and develop better borrowing habits. This was very rewarding and many learners appreciated being able to speak with someone about their loans and make decisions that will help them in their future.
cons: It turned out we became the "dumping station" for the financial aid office. Since we know how to do it make us do everything in financial aid and then some.

review_title: Clean, organize, add, swap, and remove Computer Hardware from Work Desks Stations, Conference Rooms, and meeting rooms
pros: Great Culture, good communication, Very open
cons: Always busy, must stay committed,

pros: People are very friendly to work with

job_title: Financial Aid Processor in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Health insurance was affordable.  You can work from home if you're lucky.  Free tuition, but only a positive if you think Capella will actually look good on a resume.  Free pop.  Casual dress.
cons: Extremely unrealistic data entry goals.  Given perks like flex-schedule and work from home only to have them taken away when you inevitably don't meet said goals.  Literally tied to a desk and every single thing you do is watched, monitored, recorded and reported on.  Easy to move up in your department but impossible to move to other departments.  Zero ability to network and wasn't even allowed to socialize with colleagues on my own team.  Exhausting difficult work for extremely low pay.  Didn't even get a cost of living raise which means I was technically making less my second year.  High turnover that clearly benefits those in the higher paying trainer roles.  Unfriendly coworkers.

review_title: Proceed w/ caution and avoid this department
job_title: Financial Aid Advisor in Minneapolis, MN
pros: What can I other than your teammates.  They are what gets you through the slog.
cons: Management is transitioning the current roles w/o increasing pay to accommodate.  Know that there is very high turnover rate in this office.  The contact center is on the bottom rung of Capella despite being such a crucial part a students academic journey.  It's definitely not worth being micromanaging and answering for actions outside of your control.  People come here to leave elsewhere.  There are few that stay longer than 2 years.

job_title: Financial Aid Advisor in Minneapolis, MN
pros: The job is downtown.  Skyway is nice.
cons: Expect complete isolation here with zero team involvement.  I went days without even speaking to a single person face-to-face.  The teams don’t communicate and are very cliquey.  The systems are difficult and outdated and break all the time.  Everything is so needlessly complicated that it makes your job a million times more difficult than it should be.  The supreme lack of employee engagement of any kind made it hard to show up most days.  Even when there were team outings there was zero structure and no effort to break the ice between the groups.  Everyone just sat around uncomfortable and only talked to the few people they know.

pros: Higher ed is a meaningful and exciting industry to be in and Capella has been a respected leader in the online space for a long time.  The people in general are friendly and office is in a great location with ever-increasing access to amenities.
cons: In the last year it feels like we're ungoing a massive personality shift with an increased focus on 'innovation' without substantial direction on its ultimate purpose or vision except the bottom dollar.

review_title: Great Culture, Decline in Attractive Benefits
pros: Autonomy in work, great company culture, team culture varies by manager. Recent improvements in flexible work from home options. Really focused on the learner and acting in the best interest of students. Non pushy, consultative approach to sales. New shift in valuing innovation and technology but software and means to deliver are lacking.
cons: Recent changes to benefits due to merger with Strayer have had a negative impact. Career Development is a struggle. High Turnover in leadership roles makes it hard to advance within role or manage expectations.

job_title: Financial Aid Counselor in Minneapolis, MN
pros: CEO cares about the direction of the company and has a humble approach in his leadership . He shows he hasn’t forgotten how it feels to work your way to the top.
cons: Financial Aid Department is overwhelmed with work. Too many redundant systems to work out of. Lack of communication between Departments

job_title: Financial Services Advisor in Minneapolis, MN

review_title: Great location, fun people, but bad overall org direction.
